```{r}
dat <- readxl::read_xls('GSS.xls')
dat

names(dat) <- c('Year','Happiness', 'Party', 'Earners', 'Race','Sex','Age', 'Children', 'Marital', 'ID', 'Ballot')
dat
```

```{r}
library(ggplot2)

dat <- dat[!is.na(dat$Marital), ]
dat <- dat[!is.na(dat$Happiness), ]

ggplot(dat, aes(x= Marital, fill= Happiness)) + geom_bar(position = "fill") + ggtitle("Marital Status Grouped by Happiness")
```

Married people had the highest rate of very happy or pretty happy people. This was followed by those that were never married. People that were seperated had the highest rate of being not too happy. The highest rate of a respondent having not applicable as there happiness rating was those who answered 'No answer' for Marital Status.
